Institutional Setting: Why This Is A Clean Setup
The ITC Import Relief Process

U.S. International Trade Commission investigates injury to domestic producers
Profitability is an explicit factor in injury determination
Tariff increases/quota reductions are granted if the industry is deemed injured

Perfect Alignment of Incentives

Managers want to appear injured ‚á¢ decrease earnings
Debtholders tolerate lower earnings (expect relief benefits)
No sophisticated monitoring by regulator







Critical Feature


The ITC does not verify any information in the audited financial statements or 10-Ks, nor do they make any adjustments to these data‚Ä¶ The ITC does not attempt to adjust the financial data for accounting procedures used or for accrual decisions made by the firms‚Äô managers

Main Hypothesis
Managers of domestic producers make accounting choices that reduce reported earnings during ITC investigation periods compared to non-investigation periods

Conflicting incentives?

Usually managers increase earnings (debt covenants, compensation)
But import relief benefit outweighs these concerns

Free-rider problem?

All industry firms benefit, but only some may manage earnings
Solution: Supplemental test using only petitioner firms (that bear investigation costs)

Sample Selection

Matching Import Relief Investigations to Industries and Compustat Firms
I identify import relief investigations from the U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC) by scraping their Commission Publications Library. My scraping process employs robust retry logic and Cloudflare bypass mechanisms, with raw HTML cached for reproducibility and efficiency. I match investigation titles to standardized industry classifications using a SIC-NAICS crosswalk (1987/1997 versions) enhanced by semantic matching via a local language model. This procedure links (almost) each USITC investigation ID to corresponding SIC and NAICS codes, enabling systematic identification of treatment industries (those under investigation) and control industries (structurally similar but not investigated). ImportantSome important caveats about the matching process:




I only use safeguard investigations (not other types of import relief)
Some investigations could not be matched to a specific SIC code (9999)
The matching relies on LLM reasoning which may introduce errors





Accounting Data
I obtain financial statement data from Compustat North America for U.S. incorporated firms beginning in 1975. I exclude financial institutions (SIC codes 6000-6999) and require non-missing total assets for all firm-years. To ensure robust industry-specific estimation of the Jones model, I retain only industry-years (three-digit SIC level) with at least 10 observations. I exclude observations with missing values for total accruals, revenue changes, property-plant-equipment, or lagged total assets. All continuous variables are winsorized at the 1st and 99th percentiles to reduce the influence of extreme outliers. For additional implementation details, see the companion R script.


Treatment Sample Selection and Event Window Definition
To construct my treatment sample, I apply several critical filters to the matched investigations. First, I identify the investigation date and extract both the calendar year and month. To ensure that year_zero captures the last complete fiscal year before the investigation announcement, I adjust for each firm‚Äôs fiscal year-end month. Specifically, for firms with fiscal year-end months before the investigation month, their fiscal year statement would have already been reported before the investigation, making that fiscal year ‚Äúyear 0.‚Äù For firms with fiscal year-end months after the investigation month, their reported year 0 encompasses the investigation announcement, and I adjust their timing accordingly. Second, I address the issue of multiple investigations in the same industry. Some SIC-3 industries (314, 332, 514) experience multiple import relief investigations within short time windows. To avoid contamination and confounded treatment effects, I retain only the first investigation per SIC-3 industry, excluding subsequent treatments within the same year or immediately following year (diff_year_zero > 1). This design choice prioritizes clean identification of the initial shock at the cost of sample size‚Äîa conservative approach that trades statistical power for causal credibility.











The OG‚Ä¶ Jones Model

Jones (1991): Time-Series Firm-Specific Approach
\[ \frac{\text{Total accruals}_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}} = \frac{1}{AT_{i,t-1}} + \beta_1 \frac{\Delta REV_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}} + \beta_2 \frac{PPE_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}} + \epsilon_{it}\]
Where:

\(\frac{\text{Total accruals}_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}}\) = total accruals for firm i at time t
\(AT_{i,t-1}\) = total assets for firm i at time t-1
\(\Delta REV_{it}\) = change in revenues for firm i at time t
\(PPE_{it}\) = property, plant, and equipment for firm i at time t

Jones (1991) estimates a separate regression for each firm using several years of historical data. The estimation period stops in year t-2. Firm-specific coefficients capture each firm‚Äôs unique accrual patterns. Compares actual accruals to the firm‚Äôs own historical norm.






ImportantTime-Series Firm-Specific Jones Model



Discretionary accruals: \(\text{DA}_{it}\) = residual from firm i‚Äôs time-series regression




My Approach: Cross-Sectional Industry-Specific Approach
Estimates yearly regressions by SIC-3 industry using all firms in that industry. Industry-year-specific coefficients capture industry norms in each period. Compares firm accruals to industry peers in the same year.






ImportantCross-Sectional Industry-Specific Jones Model



\(\text{DA}_{it}\) = residual from industry-year cross-sectional regression
Implication: I measure abnormal accruals relative to contemporaneous industry peers, not firm‚Äôs historical pattern








NoteDeep Dive: Earnings Management Measurement



Dechow et al. (2010) reviews the literature surrounding ‚Äúearnings quality,‚Äù including earnings management. They discuss trade-offs between time-series and cross-sectional approaches to measuring abnormal accruals. See Gow and Ding (2024) for an in-depth overview of implementing accrual-based earnings management measures‚Äîor for practical guidance on many aspects of empirical research in accounting.





Stacked Difference-in-Differences with First-Differenced Specification
I implement a stacked difference-in-differences (DiD) design to estimate the impact of import relief investigations on discretionary accruals. The treatment group consists of firms in industries subject to import relief investigations, while the control group includes firms in industries without such investigations (different SIC-1 codes). I define event time relative to the investigation year, with t=0 as the investigation year. For each event window (t-2 to t+2), I create a separate dataset stacking observations from treated and control industries; see, e.g., Baker et al. (2022); Baker et al. (2025) for more details on stacked DiD designs.

First-Difference DiD Model
\[\Delta \text{DA}_{it} = \beta_1Treated_i + \alpha_{fyear}+ \gamma_{cohort}+ \epsilon_{it}\]
Where:

\(\Delta(DA_{it}) = \text{DA}_{it} - \text{DA}_{i,t-1}\) is the change in discretionary accruals for firm i at time t
\(Treated_i\) is a binary indicator for whether firm i is in the treatment group
\(\alpha_{fyear}\) are fixed effects for the fiscal year
\(\gamma_{cohort}\) are fixed effects for the cohort
\(\epsilon_{it}\) is the error term



Why?
The idea is to present results in a way that is more directly comparable to Jones (1991). She also compares changes in discretionary accruals around the investigation period, specifically in years t-1 to t+1. I want to make my results more directly comparable to hers.






NoteOkay, so where‚Äôs the DiD?



Difference #1: Change in discretionary accruals within firms over time. First differencing removes firm fixed effects.
Difference #2: Difference in changes between treated and control industries over time. The coefficient on \(Treated_i\) captures the average difference in changes in discretionary accruals between treated and control industries.

text:
Paper Summary
Research Question
The paper investigates whether domestic producers that stand to gain from U.S. import relief manipulate earnings during investigations by the United States International Trade Commission (ITC). It seeks to fill a gap in the literature by providing empirical evidence on earnings management specifically in the context of import‚Äërelief determinations, a setting where managers‚Äô incentives to distort profitability are theoretically strong but rarely tested.
Contribution
The study supplies novel evidence that managers deliberately reduce reported earnings through discretionary accruals during ITC investigation periods. It introduces a firm‚Äëspecific expectations model that controls for economic conditions, applies it to a large Compustat sample of domestic producers, and demonstrates statistically significant earnings‚Äëmanagement effects across multiple industries.
Theory
The analysis rests on incentive theory: regulators and firms benefit from import relief, and managers of affected firms have a motive to influence the ITC‚Äôs injury assessment. The earnings‚Äëmanagement hypothesis posits that managers will lower discretionary accruals during the investigation year to make the firm appear less profitable and thereby increase the likelihood of protection.
Economic Mechanism
Import‚Äërelief decisions are based on industry profitability metrics. By decreasing earnings through discretionary accruals, managers can lower the firm‚Äôs reported profitability, making the industry appear more injured and thus more likely to receive tariffs, quotas, or other assistance. This manipulation directly links managerial accounting choices to the outcome of the ITC investigation.
Research Design
The empirical strategy uses audited financial statements from Compustat (1961‚Äë1985) and ITC filings to identify domestic producers subject to import‚Äërelief investigations. Total accruals are calculated from current assets, liabilities, and depreciation, and nondiscretionary accruals are estimated via an expectations regression on revenue change, PPE, and lagged assets. Discretionary accruals are the residuals, standardized into Vits and Z statistics. The design compares year‚ÄØ0 (the investigation year) to year‚ÄØ‚Äì1 and year‚ÄØ+1, employing portfolio tests by industry to mitigate cross‚Äësectional correlation.
Results
Discretionary accruals are significantly negative in year‚ÄØ0 across all five industries (overall t‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ‚Äì5.008, p‚ÄØ<‚ÄØ0.001). Year‚ÄØ‚Äì1 shows no significant effect, while year‚ÄØ+1 remains negative but insignificant. Z statistics for year‚ÄØ0 range from ‚Äì3.802 to ‚Äì3.137, indicating strong earnings‚Äëmanagement activity, with the footwear industry example yielding the most pronounced effect. Average R¬≤ of the accrual‚Äëexpectations regressions is 0.232, and decile analysis suggests the model remains adequate except for firms with extreme revenue declines.
Conclusion
The findings confirm that managers of domestic producers engage in earnings management during ITC investigations to influence import‚Äërelief outcomes. This evidence supports the earnings‚Äëmanagement hypothesis and highlights the need for regulators to scrutinize accruals in injury assessments. The study underscores the importance of robust accounting controls and suggests that policy reforms could mitigate managerial incentives to distort profitability in trade‚Äëpolicy contexts.

title: Company Websites A New Measure Of Disclosure - Research Summary
text:
Paper Summary
Research Question
The paper investigates whether company websites constitute a meaningful channel for public disclosure and how the extent of website disclosure relates to information asymmetry and capital‚Äëmarket outcomes. It addresses a gap in the literature that has largely focused on regulatory filings, overlooking the growing use of websites‚Äîespecially by private firms and for non‚Äëfinancial information.
Contribution
The authors develop a novel, data‚Äëdriven measure of website disclosure using historical snapshots from the Wayback Machine. They validate this measure against established proxies (management forecasts, 8‚ÄëK word counts, 10‚ÄëK file size, disclosure quality) and demonstrate its predictive power for reducing bid‚Äëask spreads and for attracting private‚Äëequity transactions. The study also maps website content into substantive categories (PSP, IR, geography, HR) and explores determinants of disclosure for both public and private firms.
Theory
The analysis rests on disclosure and signaling theory: firms disclose information to reduce asymmetry and signal quality to investors and other stakeholders. Recent evidence that U.S. firms substitute EDGAR filings with website content since 2008 underpins the theoretical expectation that richer website disclosure should improve market efficiency. The categorization of website content reflects the idea that firms tailor information to the informational needs of distinct audiences (customers, investors, regulators).
Economic Mechanism
Extensive website disclosure provides timely, accessible information that lowers investors‚Äô uncertainty, thereby narrowing bid‚Äëask spreads. For private firms, a larger, more informative website signals firm quality and transparency, making them more attractive to equity investors and increasing the likelihood of private‚Äëequity transactions. The mechanism is mediated by the volume and type of content (e.g., investor relations, product details) that directly addresses stakeholder information demands.
Research Design
The empirical strategy combines archival web data (Wayback Machine) with firm‚Äëlevel financial and market data from COMPUSTAT, CRSP, IBES, Orbis, and Zephyr. The public‚Äëfirm sample includes 5,234 U.S. firms with 198,316 firm‚Äëquarter observations (1997‚Äë2020); the private‚Äëfirm sample comprises 2.8‚ÄØmillion firms, with a subset of 371 French public firms. Website size is measured as the natural log of total bytes, and content shares are derived from bag‚Äëof‚Äëwords analyses. Outcomes include the natural log of bid‚Äëask spreads and the probability of a private‚Äëequity transaction. Estimation employs OLS regressions with year‚Äëquarter, industry, and firm fixed effects, clustering standard errors at the firm or industry level, and controlling for established disclosure proxies.
Results
Website size is strongly positively correlated with management forecasts, voluntary 8‚ÄëK word counts, disclosure quality, and 10‚ÄëK file size, confirming its validity as a disclosure proxy. After controlling for firm, industry, and time effects, larger website size is associated with significantly lower bid‚Äëask spreads. Public‚Äëfirm regressions show that larger firms, B2B firms, and those with more analyst coverage have larger websites. For private firms, a 10‚ÄØ% increase in website size raises the probability of a 2019 equity transaction by approximately 2.6‚ÄØ%, a statistically significant elasticity. Compliance with the French Gender Equality Index is positively linked to higher website disclosure, with private firms exhibiting lower compliance but greater strategic prominence.
Conclusion
The study establishes company websites as a credible, informative disclosure channel that reduces information asymmetry and facilitates capital access, particularly for private firms. The findings suggest that firms should invest in comprehensive, stakeholder‚Äëtailored web content, and that regulators might consider encouraging website disclosure as a complement to traditional filings. Future research could extend this framework to other jurisdictions and explore the causal impact of website disclosure on firm performance.

Paper Summary

Paper Summary
Research Question
The paper investigates how longitudinal website data can be systematically harvested and leveraged to study organizational discourse and strategy. It addresses the knowledge gap that, despite the abundance of archived webpages, researchers lack a reliable, scalable pipeline and a comprehensive, open‚Äëaccess database to conduct large‚Äëscale, time‚Äëseries analyses of firm communication.
Contribution
The authors deliver an open‚Äësource Python codebase that implements a four‚Äëstep scraping workflow‚Äîsample construction, Wayback Machine retrieval, preprocessing, and analysis‚Äîyielding the CompuCrawl database. This resource contains 11,277 North American firms, 86,303 firm‚Äëyear observations, and 1.6‚ÄØmillion webpages (1996‚Äë2020). The paper also demonstrates the database‚Äôs utility through a word‚Äëembedding study of the evolving meaning of ‚Äúsustainability,‚Äù and outlines future research avenues enabled by multimodal, historical web data.
Theory
The study is grounded in data‚Äësource theory (Landers‚ÄØet‚ÄØal.,‚ÄØ2016), which guides the assessment of archival data suitability for research. It also draws on conceptual frameworks of organizational identity, distinctiveness, and strategic group formation, operationalized through topic modeling and word‚Äëembedding techniques that capture semantic shifts over time.
Economic Mechanism
Website content is treated as a proxy for organizational discourse; changes in the language and structure of webpages reflect shifts in strategic priorities and stakeholder communication. The causal logic posits that as firms evolve their public messaging‚Äîe.g., increasing emphasis on sustainability‚Äîtheir website text will exhibit measurable changes in word semantics and topic prevalence, which can be quantified through embeddings and topic models.
Research Design
The empirical approach combines archival data collection with advanced text analytics. Firm identifiers are drawn from Compustat North America; archived webpages are retrieved from the Wayback Machine for 1996‚Äë2020. After rigorous cleaning (removal of invalid, non‚ÄëEnglish, and short pages) and classification via GPT‚Äë3.5, the authors aggregate front‚Äëpage and sub‚Äëpage texts into firm‚Äëyear observations. They then apply a correlated topic model (125 topics) and continuous bag‚Äëof‚Äëwords word‚Äëembedding models, aligning embeddings across five‚Äëyear periods with orthogonal Procrustes to track semantic evolution.
Results
The CompuCrawl database contains 1,617,675 webpages and 636,318,656 words across 86,303 firm‚Äëyear observations. The word‚Äëembedding analysis shows that the meaning of ‚Äúsustainability‚Äù shifts markedly over time (cosine similarity rising from 0.301 in 2001‚Äë2005 to 0.916 in 2016‚Äë2020), whereas ‚Äúprofitability‚Äù remains stable (similarity >‚ÄØ0.74 across all periods). Topic modeling yields 125 coherent topics, and GPT‚Äë3.5 classification achieves a Krippendorff‚Äôs Œ± of 0.79 against human coders. Coverage analysis indicates that missingness due to non‚Äëarchived websites is largely random and does not bias the sample.
Conclusion
Longitudinal website data, when systematically harvested and processed, offers a rich, underexploited source for organizational research. The CompuCrawl database and accompanying codebase enable scholars to examine temporal changes in corporate discourse, identity, and strategic positioning at scale. The paper demonstrates that word‚Äëembedding and topic‚Äëmodeling techniques can uncover meaningful semantic shifts, and it highlights future opportunities for multimodal analysis, generative‚ÄëAI classification, and comparative studies of strategic groups and distinctiveness.

2.1 Slide 3-4: Haans & Mertens (2024) ‚Äì The Internet Never Forgets

2.1.1 Introducing the Wayback Machine (Slide 3)
This paper provides the methodological backbone for all website-based research. The key insight is that the Internet Archive‚Äôs Wayback Machine allows researchers to access historical snapshots of organizational websites‚Äîturning the web into a longitudinal data source.
Key teaching points:
The Wayback Machine (archive.org) has been archiving web pages since 1996, currently holding over 850 billion archived page versions. This represents an unprecedented source of organizational data that captures voluntary disclosure choices firms make about themselves.
Point students to the screenshot on the slide. The ‚Äútime banner‚Äù interface lets users navigate to any archived snapshot of a website. For research purposes, this means we can observe how firms presented themselves at different points in time‚Äîbefore and after events, across economic cycles, during regulatory changes.
Why this matters for accounting research:
Websites reveal what organizations choose to emphasize. Unlike mandated filings (10-Ks, 10-Qs), website content is largely voluntary. This makes it valuable for studying: corporate disclosure strategy, investor relations practices, CSR communication evolution, and strategic messaging to various stakeholders.
The CompuCrawl Database:
Haans & Mertens don‚Äôt just provide a tutorial‚Äîthey built and released an open-access database covering 11,277 North American Compustat firms from 1996-2020, with 86,303 firm-year observations and over 1.6 million webpages. This dramatically lowers the barrier to entry for researchers.






ImportantCritical Point



Website disclosure is voluntary and targeted at multiple audiences (not just investors). This distinguishes it from traditional disclosure measures based on regulatory filings.




2.1.2 Sample Selection & Coverage (Slide 4)
This slide addresses the elephant in the room: data quality and coverage limitations.
Sampling Steps (direct students to the Appendix button):
The four-step process (sample construction ‚Üí data collection ‚Üí processing ‚Üí analysis) provides a template for any web scraping research project. Key decisions include: defining the research question, legal due diligence, determining scraping parameters, and cleaning/validating the data.
Critical Findings on Coverage:

~20% missingness rate: In any given year, approximately 20% of company websites are not archived by the Wayback Machine. This appears to be random rather than systematic‚ÄîHaans & Mertens show that firm size, profitability, and visibility do not predict whether a website was archived.
Survivorship bias from Compustat: The database backfills successful firms, meaning early-period coverage may overrepresent eventual survivors.
Website address changes not tracked: If a company changes its domain name, historical linkage can be lost. This is particularly problematic for firms undergoing rebranding or mergers.
Coverage improves over time: Early years (1990s) have poor coverage; 2010+ is much better. This creates a temporal limitation for long-horizon studies.

Comparison to traditional data:
The authors benchmark website data coverage against common Compustat variables. Website coverage eventually exceeds that of net income in recent years‚Äîsuggesting this data source is not inherently worse than traditional accounting data.

Discussion: What types of research questions might be particularly sensitive to the 20% annual missingness rate? When might it be acceptable versus problematic?







ImportantTakeaway #1



Website data offers unprecedented longitudinal access, BUT requires careful attention to coverage gaps and data quality. The ~20% random missingness and survivorship bias are real concerns that require explicit treatment in research design.

2.2 Slide 5-6: Boulland et al.¬†(2025) ‚Äì Company Websites: A New Measure of Disclosure

2.2.1 Research Question & Contributions (Slide 5)
This paper moves from ‚Äúhow to collect‚Äù to ‚Äúwhat can we measure.‚Äù Boulland, Bourveau, and Breuer propose using company websites as a novel disclosure measure‚Äîparticularly valuable for studying private firms and non-investor-targeted communication.
Motivation:
Traditional disclosure research focuses heavily on SEC filings, conference calls, and analyst interactions‚Äîall investor-centric channels available primarily for public firms. But firms communicate with many stakeholders (customers, employees, suppliers, regulators) through their websites. This channel has been largely ignored in academic research despite practitioners viewing it as essential.
Key Contributions:

Proposes website size as a disclosure proxy: The primary measure is total website size in bytes, including text, media, and applications. Larger websites represent more disclosure.
Validates against traditional measures: Website size correlates positively with management forecasts, voluntary 8-K filings, and disclosure quality measures‚Äîbut is not subsumed by them.
Extends to private firms: This is perhaps the most important contribution. Traditional disclosure measures simply don‚Äôt exist for private firms. Boulland et al.¬†construct website-based measures for millions of U.S. private firms using Bureau van Dijk‚Äôs Orbis database.
Cross-country applicability: They demonstrate the measure works for French firms (public and private), opening possibilities for international research.



2.2.2 Measurement & Validation (Slide 6)
How they measure website disclosure:

Primary measure: Natural log of total website size in bytes
Content categories: Products/Strategy/Processes (PSP), Investor Relations (IR), Geography, Human Resources‚Äîidentified through URL string patterns
Components: Text, media (images/video), applications (PDFs, etc.)

Validation approach (direct attention to Appendix):
The authors correlate their website-size measure with four established disclosure measures: management forecasts, disclosure quality (disaggregation of financial statements), voluntary 8-K filings, and 10-K file size. All correlations are positive and significant.
More importantly, they show website size is negatively associated with bid-ask spreads even after controlling for these traditional measures. If website disclosure were pure noise, we wouldn‚Äôt expect this incremental negative relationship with information asymmetry.
Applications (Appendix slides):

Private Equity Deals: For U.S. private firms, larger website size is associated with higher probability of receiving PE investment‚Äîconsistent with disclosure reducing information asymmetry for potential investors.
Nonfinancial Disclosures in France: They examine compliance with a French mandate requiring firms to disclose Gender Equality Index scores on their websites. This showcases how website data can measure responses to non-financial disclosure regulations.

The Devil‚Äôs Advocate (important teaching moment):
Direct students to the final Appendix slide on this paper. The low correlations between website size and traditional disclosure measures admit two interpretations:

Optimistic: Websites capture different information‚Äîmulti-stakeholder, real-time, voluntary‚Äîso low correlation is expected and desirable
Pessimistic: Low correlation reflects measurement noise, not true disclosure. Website size might capture marketing fluff rather than information content







ImportantTakeaway #2



Website-based measures complement traditional disclosure metrics BUT validity questions remain. The measure‚Äôs strength (broad availability, multi-stakeholder focus) is also its weakness (less standardized, potentially noisy). Interpret with appropriate caution.

text:
2.5 Slide 9-12: Jones (1991) ‚Äì Earnings Management During Import Relief Investigations

2.5.1 Research Question & Main Finding (Slide 9)
The Research Question:
Do firms that would benefit from import relief attempt to decrease earnings through earnings management during ITC investigations?
This is a specific, directional prediction‚Äînot just ‚Äúdo firms manage earnings?‚Äù but ‚Äúdo they manage earnings downward in a setting with clear incentives to appear injured?‚Äù
The Main Finding:
Managers of domestic producers significantly decrease reported earnings during import relief investigations. Specifically:

Discretionary accruals are income-decreasing in the investigation year (Year 0)
No significant effect in surrounding years (-1, +1)

This temporal precision is crucial‚Äîit‚Äôs not that these firms always have low accruals, but that accruals are specifically low during the investigation period.
Methodological Contribution:
Jones developed firm-specific time-series models to estimate ‚Äúnormal‚Äù accruals. The famous ‚ÄúJones Model‚Äù for measuring discretionary accruals emerged from this paper. While subsequent research has modified and critiqued the model extensively (Modified Jones, performance-matching, Dechow-Dichev approach), the core insight‚Äîthat abnormal accruals can proxy for earnings management‚Äîremains foundational.
Theoretical Contribution:
This was one of the first studies examining income-decreasing earnings management. Prior work focused primarily on upward manipulation (bonus maximization, debt covenant avoidance, IPO pricing). Jones showed that when the incentive structure points downward, managers respond accordingly.
The paper also demonstrates that accounting numbers have economic consequences in regulatory settings‚Äîthe ITC‚Äôs injury determination creates real wealth transfers (from consumers to domestic producers via tariffs/quotas).

Discussion: Why might income-decreasing earnings management be harder to detect than income-increasing manipulation? What monitoring mechanisms exist for each?



2.5.2 Institutional Setting: Why This Is Clean (Slide 10)
The ITC Import Relief Process:
The U.S. International Trade Commission investigates claims that domestic producers are being injured by foreign imports. If injury is found, relief can include tariff increases or import quotas‚Äîsubstantial economic benefits for domestic producers.
Why profitability matters:
Critically, profitability is an explicit factor in the ITC‚Äôs injury determination. The trade statute requires consideration of domestic industry financial health. This creates a direct link between accounting numbers and regulatory outcomes.
Perfect Alignment of Incentives:
This is what makes the setting so clean for earnings management research:

Managers want to appear injured ‚Üí decrease earnings
Debtholders tolerate lower earnings because they expect relief benefits to improve future cash flows
Shareholders benefit from relief ‚Üí no resistance to downward management
Employees benefit from industry protection ‚Üí aligned with management
The regulator doesn‚Äôt adjust: Jones‚Äôs interviews with ITC staff revealed they do NOT verify or adjust the audited financial statement data







ImportantCritical Feature



‚ÄúThe ITC does not verify any information in the audited financial statements or 10-Ks, nor do they make any adjustments to these data‚Ä¶ The ITC does not attempt to adjust the financial data for accounting procedures used or for accrual decisions made by the firms‚Äô managers.‚Äù


This quote (from Jones‚Äôs paper) is essential. Unlike many regulatory settings where sophisticated monitors might adjust for manipulation, the ITC took accounting numbers at face value.


2.5.3 Sample Industries (Slide 11)
Five Industries, Six Investigations (1980-1985):
Jones studied ‚Äúescape clause‚Äù investigations (Section 201 of the Trade Act)‚Äîcases where domestic producers seek relief from increased imports. The industries were: automobiles, copper, carbon steel, footwear, and stainless steel.
Point students to the table showing the specific investigations and their timing.
Sample Characteristics:

23 firms with complete Compustat data
Firms had broad product lines (material to consolidated financials)
Excluded: foreign-owned subsidiaries, firms opposing relief, diversified conglomerates, firms with insufficient time-series data

The sample is small by modern standards, but the power comes from the clean identification, not sample size.


2.5.4 Hypothesis Development (Slide 12)
Main Hypothesis:
Managers make accounting choices that reduce reported earnings during investigation periods compared to non-investigation periods.
Addressing Potential Concerns:
Conflicting incentives: Usually managers want to increase earnings (bonus plans, debt covenants, stock price). Jones argues the import relief benefit dominates these concerns because: (1) the stakes are high, (2) debtholders are willing to waive covenants given expected relief benefits, and (3) future earnings are expected to improve post-relief.
Free-rider problem: If one firm manipulates but others don‚Äôt, the manipulating firm still benefits from industry-wide relief. Solution: Jones conducts supplemental tests using only petitioner firms‚Äîthose that bore the cost of filing the petition‚Äîwho have the strongest incentives.


2.5.5 Empirical Results (Slide 13)
The Jones Model:
\[\frac{\text{Total accruals}_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}} = \frac{1}{AT_{i,t-1}} + \beta_1 \frac{\Delta REV_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}} + \beta_2 \frac{PPE_{it}}{AT_{i,t-1}} + \epsilon_{it}\]
The model captures ‚Äúnormal‚Äù accruals as a function of revenue growth (accruals for receivables, inventory) and PPE (depreciation). The residual is the ‚Äúdiscretionary‚Äù component.
Key Results:

Year -1: Discretionary accruals not significantly different from zero
Year 0 (investigation): Significantly income-decreasing (t-statistic = -5.008)
Year +1: Not significantly different from zero

This pattern is exactly what the hypothesis predicts‚Äîmanipulation occurs specifically during the investigation window.
Robustness:

Portfolio tests control for cross-sectional correlation (firms in the same industry investigated simultaneously)
Results hold when each industry is omitted one at a time (four-industry t-statistics range from -3.635 to -5.035)
Petitioner subsample shows consistent results







ImportantKey Implication



Managers systematically manipulate accruals downward specifically during investigation periods. The temporal precision‚Äîeffects in Year 0 but not surrounding years‚Äîprovides strong support for the earnings management hypothesis.




2.5.6 Why This Design Is Pretty Darn Good (Slide 14)
Clear Incentive Alignment:

Regulatory rule explicitly uses accounting profitability
All contracting parties benefit from appearing injured
Regulator doesn‚Äôt adjust for earnings management

Powerful Research Design:

Time-series control for firm-specific ‚Äúnormal‚Äù accruals
Clear prediction: decrease in investigation year only
Multiple industries, multiple years
Addresses free-rider problem with petitioner subsample

What makes this setting rare:
Most earnings management settings involve competing incentives and sophisticated monitors. Here, everyone is on the same side, and the regulator is unsophisticated. This creates an almost textbook-perfect setting for detecting manipulation.






NoteConnection to Part 2



‚ÄúJones‚Äôs 1991 paper is now 35 years old. The setting remains as clean as ever‚ÄîITC investigations still occur, profitability still matters for injury determination. But now we have website data. What might firms communicate on their websites during import relief investigations? And do those communications correlate with their accruals management?‚Äù

3.2 Phase 1: The Replication Journey

3.2.1 Slide 16: What I Set Out to Replicate
Jones (1991) Main Finding:

Income-decreasing discretionary accruals in Year 0
Clean institutional setting
Time-series firm-specific estimation

My Approach:

Cross-sectional industry-specific (pooled) estimation
Modern sample (1980-2020)
Stacked difference-in-differences design

Why cross-sectional instead of time-series?
This is a key methodological choice to explain. Jones estimated separate regressions for each firm using their full history. I estimate industry-year regressions using all firms in that industry.








Dimension
Jones Original
My Replication




Estimation approach
Time-series (firm-specific)
Cross-sectional (industry)


Data requirements
Long firm history
Industry observations


What it controls for
Firm-specific effects
Industry dynamics


Statistical power
Lower (fewer obs/firm)
Higher (pooled data)


Parameter interpretation
Firm-specific ‚Äúnormal‚Äù
Industry-specific ‚Äúnormal‚Äù



Trade-offs:
Cross-sectional estimation gains statistical power but assumes all firms in an industry have similar accrual processes. This may be reasonable for firms in the same competitive environment but loses firm-specific variation that Jones exploited.


3.2.2 Slide 17: The Timing Problem I Had to Solve
The Problem:
Fiscal years ‚â† calendar years ‚â† investigation dates. This creates ambiguity about which fiscal year constitutes ‚ÄúYear 0.‚Äù
Example:
Investigation announced: June 1985 (calendar)
Firm fiscal year ends: December 1984
Firm fiscal year ends: December 1985
Which "year" is Year 0?
If a firm‚Äôs fiscal year ends before the investigation announcement, their Year 0 financials were already set before they knew about the investigation. If the fiscal year ends after the announcement, they had time to adjust.
My Solution:
time = case_when(
  # Fiscal year ends before investigation decision
  fyear == event_year & month(datadate) < year_zero_month ~ time,
  # Fiscal year ends after investigation decision - shift time
  TRUE ~ time + 1
)
This code adjusts event time based on whether the firm‚Äôs fiscal year-end fell before or after the investigation announcement month.
Why This Matters‚ÄîA Key Insight:
When I first ran the analysis without this adjustment, effects appeared in Years -2 to -1 rather than Year 0. This ‚Äúdiscrepancy‚Äù isn‚Äôt a bug‚Äîit reveals that firms may manage earnings in anticipation of investigations. The fiscal year overlap means some ‚ÄúYear -1‚Äù observations actually capture post-announcement manipulation.






TipKey Insight



The timing ‚Äúdiscrepancy‚Äù isn‚Äôt a bug‚Äîit‚Äôs a feature revealing that firms may manage earnings in anticipation of investigations.




3.2.3 Slide 18: Finding and Linking the Investigations
The Problem:
The USITC conducts many types of investigations. Which ones match Jones‚Äôs setting?

Several investigation types: Safeguard, Antidumping, Countervailing Duty
Jones used ‚ÄúEscape Clause‚Äù cases (Section 201)‚Äîa subset of Safeguard investigations
She selected only investigations ‚Äúpertaining to a broad product line‚Äù

My Approach:
I scraped the USITC Commission Publications Library and matched investigation titles to SIC codes using:

SIC-NAICS crosswalk (1987/1997 versions)
Semantic matching via local language model (for ambiguous cases)
Manual verification of key matches

Figures to reference:

Top 5 investigation subjects (histogram)
Treatment cohorts over time (histogram)

Why this matters:
Investigation type affects incentives and sample selection. If the industry represents a small portion of consolidated sales, incentives to manage earnings are weaker. Jones specifically excluded diversified firms for this reason.






TipKey Insight



Institutional knowledge is key here. There is very much room for improvement in matching investigations to affected industries. Knowledge of investigation types is crucial for sample selection and interpretation.




3.2.4 Slide 19: Live Demo ‚Äì Replication Results
[SWITCH TO GITHUB PAGE: revisiting-jones.qmd]
Walk students through:

The coefficient on ‚ÄúTreated‚Äù in Year 0 should be negative and significant
Pre-period coefficients (Year -2, -1) test parallel trends
Post-period coefficient (Year +1) checks for reversal

Event-study visualization: The DiD-style plot shows coefficient estimates across event time. Look for:

Flat pre-trends
Sharp drop at Year 0
Possible reversal in Year +1


Reference Jones Table 5:
Point to the image of Jones‚Äôs original results table. Key comparison points:

Her Year 0 t-statistic: -5.008
Her effect magnitude: ~5.85% of lagged assets (mean abnormal accruals)

How do our estimates compare?


3.2.5 Slide 20: Replication Takeaways
What Worked:

‚úì Jones findings are robust to modern methods
‚úì Cross-sectional approach provides adequate power
‚úì Timing issue resolved with fiscal year alignment
‚úì Effects are economically and statistically significant

Open Questions:

Would time-series give identical results?

We have enough observations per firm to test this
Need to identify firms from original ITC reports (possibly automate with LLM?)

The earnings management literature has advanced:

Dechow et al.¬†(2010) reviews many model variants
Breuer (2023) proposes Bayesian combination of multiple EM measures
Chen et al.¬†(2018, 2023) critique two-step estimation approaches

Why do effects appear in Year -1 to Year 0?

Is this anticipation? Fiscal year overlap? Accrual reversal?








ImportantThe Bigger Question



Replication is validating, but not publishable. What NEW insight can we add 35 years later?

3.3.1 Slide 21: Adding Website Data ‚Äì The Hypothesis
Historical contrast:
In 1991: - One financial statement for all audiences - Limited tools for strategic communication - No firm websites existed - ITC reviews audited financials only
Today: - Multi-channel disclosure strategy - Rich web presence during investigations - Different audiences (investors, regulators, employees, customers) - Opportunity for coordinated manipulation
Research Question:
Do firms strategically manage website disclosures during import relief investigations?
Possible Mechanisms:

Emphasize ‚Äúinjury‚Äù narrative (layoffs, plant closings, foreign competition language)
De-emphasize expansion/investment language
Adjust messaging by section (IR vs Products vs Careers)
Coordinate with accruals management strategy

Data & Method:

Data source: Cleaned website text from Haans & Mertens‚Äôs CompuCrawl database
Method: Keyword frequency analysis (bag of words)

3.3.5 Slide 25: What Keeps Me Up at Night
Walk through each concern seriously‚Äîthis models how to evaluate project viability.
Concern #1: Measurement Validity
Are keywords capturing ‚Äústrategic injury narrative‚Äù or just ‚Äúwe‚Äôre in an investigation‚Äù?

Crude keyword counts miss nuance, sentiment, context
May need sophisticated NLP (FinBERT, topic modeling)

Concern #2: Wayback Coverage & Timing
Only later firm-years have snapshots available. When do websites actually get updated?

Non-random missingness could bias inference
Coverage especially poor for 1980s-1990s cases
Unlike 10-Ks (predictable timing), websites update unpredictably

Concern #3: Attribution Problem
Websites are controlled by whom? CFO? Marketing? Compliance?

If marketing controls content ‚Üí not earnings management strategy
If compliance requirement ‚Üí mechanical response, not strategic
Need to establish CFO involvement for EM interpretation

Concern #4: Spurious Correlation
Is any website-accruals-investigation correlation real or just noise?

Multiple testing concerns
Sensitivity to keyword choices
Small sample in overlapping period

Concern #5: Using different EM measures & addressing 2-stage critique?
The literature has moved beyond simple Jones residuals.

Chen et al.¬†(2018, 2023) critique two-step approaches
Breuer (2023) Bayesian framework for combining measures
Real earnings management (Roychowdhury 2006) as alternative

4.1 On the Jones Model Variants
The earnings management literature offers many variants of the Jones model:

Original Jones (1991): Time-series estimation, firm-specific coefficients
Modified Jones (Dechow et al.¬†1995): Adjusts for credit sales in event years
Performance-matched (Kothari et al.¬†2005): Matches on ROA to control for performance correlation
Dechow-Dichev (2002): Models accruals as function of cash flows
One-step approaches (Chen et al.¬†2018): Avoid bias from two-step estimation

For this lecture, we use a cross-sectional industry-year approach that‚Äôs closer to modern practice than Jones‚Äôs original time-series design. Be prepared for questions about whether results would differ with alternative specifications.

4.2 On Stacked Difference-in-Differences
The stacked DiD design (Baker et al.¬†2022) addresses concerns about negative weighting in standard two-way fixed effects with staggered treatment. Key features:

Separate dataset for each treatment cohort
Clean control group (never-treated or not-yet-treated)
Cohort-specific fixed effects

This is more computationally intensive but avoids the bias that can arise when treatment effects are heterogeneous across time.

4.3 On Website Data Timing
A recurring challenge: website snapshots from the Wayback Machine are taken at irregular intervals. Unlike quarterly financial reports with predictable timing, we don‚Äôt know exactly when website content was updated.
Possible approaches: 1. Use midpoint of fiscal year as requested timestamp (Haans & Mertens approach) 2. Request multiple snapshots per year and track changes 3. Focus on content rather than timing (assume representative snapshot)

4.4 Common Student Questions
Q: Why not replicate Jones exactly with her original sample?
A: We could, but extending to modern data and methods provides more generalizable insights. The original sample is small (23 firms); modern data allows more robust inference.
Q: How do we know the ITC still uses profitability the same way?
A: The statutory framework (Trade Act Section 201) hasn‚Äôt fundamentally changed. Profitability remains an explicit injury factor. However, the regulatory environment has evolved‚Äîworth checking current ITC practices.
Q: Isn‚Äôt keyword frequency analysis too simple?
A: Yes, but it‚Äôs a valid first pass. If there‚Äôs no signal with crude measures, sophisticated NLP probably won‚Äôt find one either. Start simple, then refine.
